The Xerces’ Society: 
Approach to pollinator 
conservation
Kass Urban-Mead PhD
Nov 29, 2023
Pollinator Conservation Specialist, Mid-Atlantic Region
The Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation
Partner Biologist
USDA National Resources Conservation Service
Photo: Jennifer Hopwood

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Background on me
1.
PhD at Cornell – 
a.
6 years studying bees in northeastern forests and 
orchards
2.
MS in Ecology at Yale School of Forestry
3.
1 year in France doing experimental work on plant 
traits greenhouse
4.
Summer internships - 
a.
farm work, “WWOOFing”
b.
horticultural work at Arboretum
5.
Extensive undergraduate research! Summer field 
work which led into senior thesis
a.
Ecology field work, taxonomy, landscape ecology
b.
Molecular lab work & microcolonies

Little things that run the world
Only a small fraction (~2%) of insects are pests. 
The rest are beneficial to humans or important for food webs
Photo: Piotr Naskrecki

© 2017 The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Nutrient 
cycling and 
decomposition
Turn plants 
into food for 
other 
animals
Pollinate wild 
& cultivated 
plants –
including our 
food!
Provide 
biological 
pest control 
Photos: (left to right): Magnus Robinson; USDA ARS Scott Bauer; Marcel Holyoak via flickr; Emily 
May / Xerces Society  Quote from NYT Editorial Insect Armageddon October 29, 2017
“The fate of the world’s insects is inseparable from our own”
Soil health, pest control, crop pollination, higher yields...

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Importance of Pollinators: Ecological Keystone
More than 85% of flowering plants require an animal, mostly insects, to move pollen.
Photo:  Sarah Greenleaf
Ollerton, Winfree & Tarrant. 2011. How many flowering plants are pollinated by animals? 
Oikos
 120:321–326

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Importance of Pollinators: Human Nutrition
•
35% of crop production, 
worldwide
•
$34 billion value of 
crops in U.S. ($217 
billion worldwide)
•
Most of our vitamins 
and minerals
Pollinators enable 
plants to produce 
fruits and seeds.
Jordan et al 2021. Economic Dependence and Vulnerability 
of 
U.S. Agricultural Sector on Insect-Mediated Pollination 
Service. Env Sci and Tech. DOI: (10.1021/acs.est.0c04786)

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Research by Brett Blaauw and Dr. Rufus Isaacs, Michigan State 
University
The Importance of Habitat
•
In 2011, Michigan 
researchers observed 
12% increase in 
blueberry yields 
adjacent to wildflower 
plantings. 
•
Increased yields may 
pay off the cost of 
establishing wildflowers 
in 3-to-4 years.
Native Plant Field 
Borders and 
Pollination
Photo: Brett Blaauw

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Habitat provides pest control benefits
If more than 20% of a 
farm is diverse habitat, 
pest control by 
beneficial insects is 
observed throughout 
fields (Tscharntke et al. 
2002). 
Lady 
Beetles
Lacewings
Parasitoid 
Wasps
Photos: Sarah Foltz Jordan, Thelma Heidel-Baker, Adam Varenhorst, Jennifer Hopwood

© 2017 The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.

fragmentation
Invasive plant species
Monoculture agriculture
Biodiversity loss

Chlorpyrifos
Fipronil
Imidacloprid

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Chemical 
Mixtures
•
Pollinator exposure to 
complex mixtures is the 
rule, not the exception
•
Using toxicity data for a 
single species 
to screen 
for 
individual 
(chemical-by-chemical) 
risk 
is likely to 
underestimate risk 
Photo: Emily May
Graham, K. K., Milbrath, M. O., Zhang, Y., Baert, N., McArt, S., & Isaacs, R. (2022). Pesticide risk to managed bees during 
blueberry pollination is primarily driven by off-farm exposures. Scientific Reports, 12(1), 7189.

Beyond LD50s: Fitness Impacts
Fewer 
offspring
Mostly male 
offspring 
(male-biased 
sex ratio)
Difficulty 
building/ 
 
provisioning 
 
nests
Lower 
overwinterin
g queen 
survival and 
nest 
initiation
Photos: Mace Vaughan (1 and 2), Jim Jasinski, Emily May
Stuligross and Williams (2021); Willis Chan and Raine (2021); Leza et al. (2018); Baron et al. (2017)

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Toxicity to 
non-
Apis 
species
•
Honey bee is 
standard test 
organism for all 
terrestrial insects
•
Some species or 
groups of insects may 
be more sensitive to 
certain pesticides
•
More data needed 
for comparison
Photo: Stephanie McKnight/Xerces

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Indirect Effects: 
Herbicides
•
Landscape-level loss of 
food plants
•
Herbicide drift = fewer 
resources, less diversity
Photo: United Soybean Board/Flickr CC. Map: USGS 
Pesticide National Synthesis Project

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Modeling 
simplifies 
complex systems
•
Modeling is a useful 
tool, but has limits
•
Critical to identify 
areas of uncertainty 
and potential bias

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Solutions: 
Risk 
Assessment
•
Refine modeling and 
assessment approaches to 
account for mixtures, 
additional endpoints and 
exposure routes, and 
differing sensitivities to 
pesticides
•
Improve data collection and 
monitoring
•
Recognize uncertainty and 
proceed with caution
Photo: Kelly Gill

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Solutions: In 
the field
•
Identify and prioritize 
locations for habitat 
that are protected from 
pesticides
•
Help growers adopt 
prevention-first pest 
management and justify 
pesticide use with 
scouting/monitoring
Photos: Thelma Heidel-Baker, Katelyn Orde

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
•
2008 Farm Bill: funding for Pollinator 
Conservation through the USDA
•
Voluntary Government programs 
provide financial assistance to farms 
implementing conservation practices
•
Natural Resources Conservation 
Service has historically been focused 
on soil health
•
So, to ensure expertise, many states 
now fund Pollinator Specialist Partner 
Biologists

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Photos: Thelma Heidel-Baker, Katelyn Orde
Custom Seed 
Mixes and Plant 
Lists
•
Take into account soils, light, 
existing species
•
Meet NRCS requirements for 
proportion milkweed, forbs, grasses
•
Ensure a diversity of high-quality 
nectar and pollen from spring 
through fall
•
Take into account generalist and 
specialist pollinators
•
Include host plants for predators 
and parasitoids of crop pests of 
concern
•
Avoid alternate hosts for known 
pests to crop trees

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Photos: Thelma Heidel-Baker, Katelyn Orde
Custom Seed 
Mixes and Plant 
Lists
•
CHALLENGES:
•
Landowner equipment, 
expertise, time, labor
•
Expected reimbursement rate 
may be low from USDA 
cost-share programs 
→
ongoing 
advocacy and collaboration
•
Seed availability 
→
ongoing 
work with nurseries to expand 
native seed availability and 
pricing

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
We know enough to act now (Forister 2019): 
Case Study #3: Community-Level Habitat:
 Habitat Kits and Peoples’ Gardens
Photo: Irene Borngraeber / Riverview Park, Jersey CIty

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Even small spaces contribute to conservation
Photo: Jim Byrne / Gold Star Park

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Habitat Kits!
●
We understand that plant materials are 
often a barrier for community groups.
●
Through the Xerces Society’s habitat kit 
program, we provide plants and resources 
to folks with the interest, experience, and 
land to make it happen. 
●
We offer carefully selected, native and 
regionally appropriate plant material 
directly to our partners for shovel-ready 
projects. 
Credit: Kass Urban-Mead / Xerces
Photo: Irene Borngraeber / Riverview Park, Jersey CIty

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Habitat Kits!
There are now kit programs in Detroit, Mid-Atlantic, 
California, Santa Fe,Oregon, and Wisconsin
 
Partners include schools, community gardens, parks, 
and farms with strong education programs.
 
 
In 2023, we also prioritized urban farms, gardens, & 
parks in NYC, Philly, & NJ.
Credit: Kass Urban-Mead / Xerces
Photo: Irene Borngraeber / Riverview Park, Jersey CIty
Photo Credit: Jess Chou / Greener Partners, Philadelphia ; Jasmin Velez / Kensington Garden Cluster, Philadelphia

© The Xerces Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Northeast Pollinator Habitat Kit Program
Building strong networks of people, plants, and pollinators
Local nursery 
working to improve 
availability of 
diverse local 
ecotypes
Important pollinator 
host plants are often 
cost- prohibitive for 
public schools & 
gardens
Planting events were 
often joyful, sweaty, 
challenging, yet 
ultimately rewarding 
community events!
Connectivity of pollinator 
habitats in food apartheid 
areas helps support 
sustainable pollination 
services for food security
Plant Nursery 
CollaborationS
Hard to Find 
Plant Species
Habitat 
and
 
Community 
Building

landscapes
